question: A 19-year-old man with a past medical history significant only for moderate facial acne and mild asthma presents to his primary care physician with a new rash. He notes it has developed primarily over the backs of his elbows and is itchy. He also reports a 6-month history of foul-smelling diarrhea. He has no significant social or family history. The patient's blood pressure is 109/82 mm Hg, pulse is 66/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). Physical examination reveals crusting vesicular clusters on his elbows with a base of erythema and edema. What is the most likely underlying condition?
generalPublicQuestion: Hey there! I've been dealing with a new itchy rash on the backs of my elbows lately. It's been bothering me quite a bit. I've also noticed that I've been having smelly diarrhea for about 6 months now. When I went to see my doctor, they found some crusting vesicular clusters on my elbows with redness and swelling underneath. Any idea what might be causing all of this?
surveyQuestions:
Hey there! I've been dealing with a new itchy rash on the backs of my elbows lately. It's been bothering me quite a bit. I've also noticed that I've been having smelly diarrhea for about 6 months now. When I went to see my doctor, they found some crusting vesicular clusters on my elbows with redness and swelling underneath. Any idea what might be causing all of this?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any fever or chills recently? I have not experienced any fever or chills.
- Are there any other areas on your body where you have noticed similar rash or skin changes? I have noticed similar rash and skin changes on my elbows and knees.
- Have you traveled to any new locations or been exposed to any new substances before the symptoms started? I have not traveled to any new locations or been exposed to any new substances.
- Have you made any changes to your diet or skincare routine recently? I have not made any changes to my diet or skincare routine recently.

question: A 21-year-old woman is brought by her mother to a psychiatrist due to concerns about her behavior. The patient’s mother tells the psychiatrist that she believes that a famous Hollywood celebrity actor loves her and will marry her. When the patient is asked about this, she says that she attended a function at which this actor was the guest of honor six months back, and he waved his hand at her by which she understood that he loves her. However, when she tries to contact him over the phone, he does not respond, which she says is probably because he is too busy with his career at present. When asked why the successful actor would marry her, she says, “Celebrities often prefer to marry ordinary people and that is why he expressed his interest in me that day”. The patient is otherwise healthy with no known medical condition. She denies any mood disturbances, hallucinations, or anxiety. She is currently working as an assistant manager at a private advertising firm and has a normal socio-occupational life. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
generalPublicQuestion: I am a 21-year-old woman and my mother is worried about me. She thinks a famous actor loves me and wants to marry me. I saw this actor at an event six months ago, and he waved at me. I feel like he loves me too, but when I try to reach out to him, he doesn't reply. I think he's just busy with his work. I work as an assistant manager at an advertising firm and have a regular life. I'm not sure why I'm feeling this way.
surveyQuestions:
I am a 21-year-old woman and my mother is worried about me. She thinks a famous actor loves me and wants to marry me. I saw this actor at an event six months ago, and he waved at me. I feel like he loves me too, but when I try to reach out to him, he doesn't reply. I think he's just busy with his work. I work as an assistant manager at an advertising firm and have a regular life. I'm not sure why I'm feeling this way.A: Additional Information:
Have you experienced any changes in your mood or behavior recently? Yes, I have been feeling more paranoid and suspicious of others.
Are you finding it difficult to focus on your work or daily activities? Yes, I have trouble concentrating and completing tasks.
Do you have trouble sleeping or changes in your appetite? Yes, I have trouble sleeping and have experienced changes in my appetite.
Have you had any previous episodes of believing someone famous is in love with you? Yes, I have believed in the past that a famous person was in love with me.
Do you have a history of mental health conditions in your family? Yes, there is a history of mental health conditions in my family.

question: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of difficulty breathing and sharp chest pain. The chest pain increases in intensity with lying down, and it radiates to the scapular ridge. Approximately 3 weeks ago, he had an anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction, which was treated with intravenous alteplase. He was discharged home in a stable condition. Current vital signs include a temperature of 38.1 (100.5°F), blood pressure of 131/91 mm Hg, and pulse of 99/min. On examination, heart sounds are distant and a scratching sound is heard on the left sternal border. ECG reveals widespread concave ST elevations in the precordial leads and PR depressions in leads V2-V6. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient condition?
generalPublicQuestion: I'm a 72-year-old man and I'm having trouble breathing and sharp pain in my chest. The pain gets worse when I lie down and goes to my shoulder blade area. About 3 weeks ago, I had a heart attack and received treatment for it. Right now, my temperature is 38.1 (100.5°F). When the doctors checked my heart, they heard distant sounds and a scratching noise on the left side of my chest. The ECG test showed some changes in my heart's electrical activity. What could be causing these symptoms for me?
surveyQuestions:
I'm a 72-year-old man and I'm having trouble breathing and sharp pain in my chest. The pain gets worse when I lie down and goes to my shoulder blade area. About 3 weeks ago, I had a heart attack and received treatment for it. Right now, my temperature is 38.1 (100.5°F). When the doctors checked my heart, they heard distant sounds and a scratching noise on the left side of my chest. The ECG test showed some changes in my heart's electrical activity. What could be causing these symptoms for me?Q: Additional Information:
Have you experienced any recent shortness of breath, dizziness, or fatigue?: I have been experiencing shortness of breath and fatigue recently.
Are you currently taking any medications for your heart condition or any other health issues?: Yes, I am taking medications for my heart condition.
Have you noticed any swelling in your legs or ankles?: Yes, I have noticed some swelling in my legs and ankles.
Have you had any recent coughing, wheezing, or chest congestion?: I have been coughing and experiencing chest congestion lately.
Have you had any recent episodes of nausea or vomiting?: I have had some episodes of nausea.
Have you had any recent weight gain or loss?: I have experienced some recent weight gain.
Have you had any recent changes in your appetite or fluid intake?: My appetite and fluid intake have been fluctuating recently.

question: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of headaches, nausea, and vomiting. During this time, she has also had recurrent dizziness and palpitations. The symptoms started while she was at a friend's birthday party, where she had one beer. One week ago, the patient was diagnosed with a genitourinary infection and started on antimicrobial therapy. She has no history of major medical illness. Her pulse is 106/min and blood pressure is 102/73 mm Hg. Physical examination shows facial flushing and profuse sweating. The patient is most likely experiencing adverse effects caused by treatment for an infection with which of the following pathogens?
generalPublicQuestion: I'm a 24-year-old woman who went to the emergency room because I've had a headache, felt nauseous, and threw up for the past 4 hours. I also felt dizzy and my heart was beating fast. These symptoms started when I was at a friend's birthday party and had one beer. A week ago, I was diagnosed with a urinary infection and started taking medicine for it. I don't have any major medical problems. The doctor noticed that my face was red and I was sweating a lot. Which infection am I likely having a reaction to from the medicine I'm taking?
surveyQuestions:
I'm a 24-year-old woman who went to the emergency room because I've had a headache, felt nauseous, and threw up for the past 4 hours. I also felt dizzy and my heart was beating fast. These symptoms started when I was at a friend's birthday party and had one beer. A week ago, I was diagnosed with a urinary infection and started taking medicine for it. I don't have any major medical problems. The doctor noticed that my face was red and I was sweating a lot. Which infection am I likely having a reaction to from the medicine I'm taking?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any itching, rash, or hives since starting the medication for the urinary infection? Yes, I have been experiencing itching and a rash since starting the medication.
- Did the doctor check your blood pressure, temperature, or pulse during your visit to the emergency room? Yes, the doctor checked my blood pressure, temperature, and pulse.
- Are you currently taking any other medications or supplements besides the one for the urinary infection? No, I am only taking the medication for the urinary infection.

question: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter because of left-sided weakness for 1 hour. She does not have headache or blurring of vision. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, type 2 diabetes, and coronary artery disease. She has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Her medications include atorvastatin, amlodipine, metformin, and aspirin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 168/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a left facial droop. Muscle strength is decreased on the left side. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the left. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration as well as two-point discrimination are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
generalPublicQuestion: I'm a 72-year-old woman who has been experiencing weakness on my left side for the past hour. I haven't had a headache or blurry vision. I have some health conditions like high blood pressure, high cholesterol, type 2 diabetes, and heart disease. I've been smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. I take medications for these conditions. My temperature is normal, and my pulse is 92 beats per minute. The doctor noticed that the left side of my face is drooping, and my left side is weaker. They also found that my left side's reflexes are stronger. My sensation to touch and other feelings on the left side are normal. I'm wondering what could be causing these symptoms.
surveyQuestions:
I'm a 72-year-old woman who has been experiencing weakness on my left side for the past hour. I haven't had a headache or blurry vision. I have some health conditions like high blood pressure, high cholesterol, type 2 diabetes, and heart disease. I've been smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. I take medications for these conditions. My temperature is normal, and my pulse is 92 beats per minute. The doctor noticed that the left side of my face is drooping, and my left side is weaker. They also found that my left side's reflexes are stronger. My sensation to touch and other feelings on the left side are normal. I'm wondering what could be causing these symptoms.A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any recent trauma or injury to your head or neck?: No
- Do you have a history of stroke or mini-strokes (TIA)?: I have a history of mini-strokes (TIA)
- Have you noticed any changes in your speech or difficulty speaking?: Yes, I have noticed changes in my speech
- Have you had any recent changes in your medications or dosage?: No
- Have you experienced any changes in your vision or hearing?: No
- Have you had any recent changes in your balance or coordination?: Yes, I have had recent changes in my balance and coordination

question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after sustaining a gunshot wound to her shoulder. During the course of the physical exam, the physician notes her spleen is palpable 10 cm below the left costal margin. Additionally, radiography of her shoulder showed several 'punched-out' areas of lytic bone. While this was considered an incidental finding at the time, she was referred to her primary care physician for further workup. Subsequent biopsy of the spleen demonstrated that this patient’s splenomegaly was caused by an infiltrative process. Which of the following processes would most likely result in splenomegaly in this patient?
generalPublicQuestion: I am a 45-year-old woman who recently went to the emergency room after getting shot in my shoulder. The doctor felt my spleen and found it to be larger than normal. They also saw some unusual areas on the x-ray of my shoulder. After further tests, they discovered that my spleen was enlarged due to something spreading through it. What could be causing my spleen to be enlarged in this situation?
surveyQuestions:
I am a 45-year-old woman who recently went to the emergency room after getting shot in my shoulder. The doctor felt my spleen and found it to be larger than normal. They also saw some unusual areas on the x-ray of my shoulder. After further tests, they discovered that my spleen was enlarged due to something spreading through it. What could be causing my spleen to be enlarged in this situation?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any unexplained weight loss recently? Yes, I have experienced unexplained weight loss.
- Do you have a history of infections or illnesses that could affect your spleen? I do not have a history of infections or illnesses that could affect my spleen.
- Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or energy levels? Yes, I have noticed changes in my appetite and energy levels.
- Are you experiencing any pain or discomfort in the abdominal area? Yes, I am experiencing pain and discomfort in the abdominal area.
- Have you had any recent blood tests to check for abnormalities in your blood cells or platelets? I have not had any recent blood tests to check for abnormalities in my blood cells or platelets.

question: A 32-year-old woman presents to a psychiatrist to discuss a recent event in her life. At a social function 2 days back, she met a man who introduced himself as having worked with her at another private company 3 years ago. However, she did not recognize him. She also says that she does not remember working at any such company at any time during her life. However, the patient’s husband says that she had indeed worked at that company for three months and had quit due to her boss’s abusive behavior towards her. The man who met her at the function had actually been her colleague at that job. The woman asks the doctor, “How is it possible? I am really not able to recall any memories of having worked at any such company. What’s going on here?”. Her husband adds that after she quit the job, her mood frequently has been low. The patient denies any crying episodes, suicidal ideas, not enjoying recreational activities or feelings of worthlessness. Her appetite and sleep patterns are normal. She is otherwise a healthy woman with no significant medical history and lives a normal social and occupational life. The patient reports no history of smoking, alcohol, or substance use. On physical examination, she is alert and well-oriented to time, place and person. During memory testing, she correctly remembers the date of her marriage that took place 5 years back and the food she ate over the last 2 days. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
generalPublicQuestion: I am a 32-year-old woman who is having trouble remembering working at a company where a man claims we were colleagues. I don't recall ever working there, but my husband says I did for three months and left because of a bad boss. I'm confused and want to know why I can't remember this. My husband mentioned that my mood has been low since I left that job, but I don't feel sad or have any other concerning thoughts. I eat and sleep well, and my daily life is normal. I don't smoke, drink alcohol, or use drugs. When tested, I remember important events like my wedding date and recent meals. What could be causing this memory issue?
surveyQuestions:
I am a 32-year-old woman who is having trouble remembering working at a company where a man claims we were colleagues. I don't recall ever working there, but my husband says I did for three months and left because of a bad boss. I'm confused and want to know why I can't remember this. My husband mentioned that my mood has been low since I left that job, but I don't feel sad or have any other concerning thoughts. I eat and sleep well, and my daily life is normal. I don't smoke, drink alcohol, or use drugs. When tested, I remember important events like my wedding date and recent meals. What could be causing this memory issue?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any head injuries or trauma recently? I don't recall any head injuries or trauma.
- Do you have a history of mental health conditions such as anxiety or depression? I have a history of anxiety.
- Have you been under increased stress or pressure at work or in your personal life? I have been under increased stress at work.
- Are you currently taking any medications that could affect your memory? I am not currently taking any medications that could affect my memory.
- Have you noticed any other cognitive issues such as difficulty concentrating or confusion? I have noticed difficulty concentrating at times.
- Have you had any recent changes in your sleep patterns or quality of sleep? I have had recent changes in my sleep patterns.

question: A 14-year-old boy presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea after returning from an East Asian vacation. Stool sample reveals the presence of red and white blood cells. Stool culture shows growth of immobile, non-lactose fermenting gram-negative rods. The attending physician explains to the medical students that the bacteria function by invading intestinal M-cells. The bacterium responsible for this patient's infection is:
generalPublicQuestion: Hey there! I've been having some tummy pain and runny poops after my trip to East Asia. The doctor checked my poop and found some red and white blood cells in it. They also found some bacteria that don't move around a lot and don't break down lactose. The doctor said these bacteria like to invade special cells in my intestines called M-cells. Can you help me figure out which bacterium is causing trouble in my belly?
surveyQuestions:
Hey there! I've been having some tummy pain and runny poops after my trip to East Asia. The doctor checked my poop and found some red and white blood cells in it. They also found some bacteria that don't move around a lot and don't break down lactose. The doctor said these bacteria like to invade special cells in my intestines called M-cells. Can you help me figure out which bacterium is causing trouble in my belly?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any fever, chills, or sweats? Yes, I have been experiencing fever and chills.
- Are you experiencing any nausea or vomiting? Yes, I have been experiencing nausea and vomiting.
- Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight? Yes, I have noticed a decrease in appetite and weight loss.
- Do you have any abdominal cramping or bloating? Yes, I have been experiencing abdominal cramping and bloating.
- Have you traveled to any other regions recently besides East Asia? No, I have not traveled to any other regions recently.

question: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, diarrhea, and crampy abdominal pain for 3 weeks. The abdominal pain is worse after eating. During the past week, he has had up to 4 watery stools daily. He has also had pain in his mouth and gums for 6 days. He has not had nausea, vomiting, or fever. Four months ago, he went on a 1-week trip to the Dominican Republic. He has atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hypothyroidism. Current medications include levothyroxine, metoprolol, and warfarin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 81/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Examination shows two 1-cm, tender ulcerative lesions in the mouth. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant without guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 77 fL, leukocyte count is 11,800 mm3, and platelet count is 360,000 mm3. Colonoscopy with biopsy of the colonic mucosa is performed. Analysis of the specimen shows non-caseating granulomas and neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
generalPublicQuestion: I have been feeling tired, having diarrhea, and experiencing crampy abdominal pain for the past 3 weeks. The pain gets worse after I eat. I've been having up to 4 watery stools every day for the past week. I've also had pain in my mouth and gums for the last 6 days. I haven't been nauseous, vomiting, or had a fever. I traveled to the Dominican Republic for a week four months ago. I have atrial fibrillation, high blood pressure, and an underactive thyroid. I take levothyroxine, metoprolol, and warfarin. I've been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. The doctor found two 1-cm tender sores in my mouth and mild tenderness in the right lower part of my belly during the exam. My blood tests show low hemoglobin, normal-sized red blood cells, high white blood cell count, and normal platelet count. The doctor did a colonoscopy and found non-caseating granulomas and inflammation in the crypts of my colon. What could be causing these symptoms?
surveyQuestions:
I have been feeling tired, having diarrhea, and experiencing crampy abdominal pain for the past 3 weeks. The pain gets worse after I eat. I've been having up to 4 watery stools every day for the past week. I've also had pain in my mouth and gums for the last 6 days. I haven't been nauseous, vomiting, or had a fever. I traveled to the Dominican Republic for a week four months ago. I have atrial fibrillation, high blood pressure, and an underactive thyroid. I take levothyroxine, metoprolol, and warfarin. I've been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. The doctor found two 1-cm tender sores in my mouth and mild tenderness in the right lower part of my belly during the exam. My blood tests show low hemoglobin, normal-sized red blood cells, high white blood cell count, and normal platelet count. The doctor did a colonoscopy and found non-caseating granulomas and inflammation in the crypts of my colon. What could be causing these symptoms?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any unintentional weight loss recently? Yes, I have experienced unintentional weight loss.
- Have you noticed any blood in your stool? Yes, I have noticed blood in my stool.
- Are you experiencing any joint pain or swelling? Yes, I am experiencing joint pain and swelling.
- Have you had any recent changes in your diet or eating habits? No, I have not had any recent changes in my diet or eating habits.
- Have you traveled anywhere else recently besides the Dominican Republic? No, I have not traveled anywhere else recently.
- Have you had any recent changes in your medications or dosage? No, I have not had any recent changes in my medications or dosage.
- Do you have a family history of gastrointestinal conditions or autoimmune diseases? Yes, there is a family history of gastrointestinal conditions and autoimmune diseases.

question: A 74-year-old man presents to the physician with a painful lesion over his right lower limb which began 2 days ago. He says that the lesion began with pain and severe tenderness in the area. The next day, the size of the lesion increased and it became erythematous. He also mentions that a similar lesion had appeared over his left lower limb 3 weeks earlier, but it disappeared after a few days of taking over the counter analgesics. There is no history of trauma, and the man does not have any known medical conditions. On physical examination, the physician notes a cordlike tender area with erythema and edema. There are no signs suggestive of deep vein thrombosis or varicose veins. Which of the following malignancies is most commonly associated with the lesion described in the patient?
generalPublicQuestion: I have a painful sore on my right leg that showed up 2 days ago. It started hurting and feeling tender, then it grew bigger and turned red. A similar sore was on my left leg 3 weeks ago but went away after taking pain medicine. I didn't injure myself, and I'm usually healthy. The doctor found a tender, red, swollen area that feels like a cord. There are no signs of blood clots or varicose veins. Which type of cancer is often linked to this kind of sore?
surveyQuestions:
I have a painful sore on my right leg that showed up 2 days ago. It started hurting and feeling tender, then it grew bigger and turned red. A similar sore was on my left leg 3 weeks ago but went away after taking pain medicine. I didn't injure myself, and I'm usually healthy. The doctor found a tender, red, swollen area that feels like a cord. There are no signs of blood clots or varicose veins. Which type of cancer is often linked to this kind of sore?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any recent trauma or injury to your legs?: No
- Are there any other symptoms present, such as fever, chills, or fatigue?: I have been experiencing fatigue lately.
- Have you noticed any changes in your skin texture or color in other areas of your body?: I have noticed some jaundice in my skin and eyes.
- Do you have a history of skin conditions or previous skin cancers?: No
- Have you been exposed to any chemicals or toxins that could irritate the skin?: Not that I am aware of
- Have you had any recent changes in your weight or appetite?: I have experienced unexplained weight loss recently.

question: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of 6 months of progressive weakness in her arms and legs. During this time, she has also had difficulty swallowing and holding her head up. Examination shows pooling of oral secretions. Muscle strength and tone are decreased in the upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the right upper and lower extremities, 3+ in the left upper extremity, and 4+ in the left lower extremity. Sensation to light touch, pinprick, and vibration are intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
generalPublicQuestion: For the past 6 months, I've been having difficulty moving my arms and legs. It's also tough for me to swallow and hold my head up. The doctor saw that my saliva is collecting in my mouth. My muscles aren't as strong as they used to be. When the doctor tested my reflexes, they were different on each side. I can still feel touch, pinpricks, and vibrations. What might be causing these symptoms?
surveyQuestions:
For the past 6 months, I've been having difficulty moving my arms and legs. It's also tough for me to swallow and hold my head up. The doctor saw that my saliva is collecting in my mouth. My muscles aren't as strong as they used to be. When the doctor tested my reflexes, they were different on each side. I can still feel touch, pinpricks, and vibrations. What might be causing these symptoms?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any changes in your speech or voice?: Yes, I have noticed changes in my speech and voice.
- Do you have any history of autoimmune disorders or neurological conditions?: No
- Have you noticed any changes in your vision or eye movements?: Yes, I have noticed changes in my vision and eye movements.
- Have you had any recent infections or illnesses?: No
- Have you traveled to any new locations recently or been exposed to any toxins or chemicals?: No
- Have you experienced any numbness or tingling in your limbs?: Yes, I have experienced numbness and tingling in my limbs.
- Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your head or neck?: No
- Have you noticed any changes in your bowel or bladder function?: Yes, I have noticed changes in my bowel and bladder function.

question:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician with a 3-month history of progressive intermittent pain and swelling involving both knees, right ankle, and right wrist. The patient has been undergoing treatment with acetaminophen and ice packs, both of which relieved her symptoms. The affected joints feel "stuck” and are difficult to move immediately upon waking up in the morning. However, the patient can move her joints freely after a few minutes. She also complains of occasional mild eye pain that resolves spontaneously. Five months ago, she was diagnosed with an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved without treatment. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swollen and erythematous joints, which are tender to touch. Slit-lamp examination shows an anterior chamber flare with signs of iris inflammation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
Blood parameters
Hemoglobin 12.6 g/dL
Leukocyte count 8,000/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 76%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 3%
Platelet count 360,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 36 mm/hr
Serum parameters
Antinuclear antibodies 1:320
Rheumatoid factor negative
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
generalPublicQuestion: For the past 3 months, I've been feeling pain and swelling in my knees, right ankle, and right wrist. When I wake up in the morning, these joints feel stiff and are hard to move, but they get better after a few minutes. Occasionally, my eyes hurt a little, but the pain goes away by itself. The doctor noticed that my joints are swollen, red, and tender. They also found signs of inflammation in my eyes. I had some blood tests done, but I'm not sure what the results mean. Can someone help me figure out what might be wrong with me?
surveyQuestions:
For the past 3 months, I've been feeling pain and swelling in my knees, right ankle, and right wrist. When I wake up in the morning, these joints feel stiff and are hard to move, but they get better after a few minutes. Occasionally, my eyes hurt a little, but the pain goes away by itself. The doctor noticed that my joints are swollen, red, and tender. They also found signs of inflammation in my eyes. I had some blood tests done, but I'm not sure what the results mean. Can someone help me figure out what might be wrong with me?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any recent weight loss or fatigue? Yes, I have been experiencing fatigue lately.
- Do you have a family history of autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis or lupus? Yes, my mother has rheumatoid arthritis.
- Have you noticed any changes in your skin, such as a rash or lesions? Yes, I have noticed a rash on my arms.
- Are you experiencing any gastrointestinal symptoms like abdominal pain or diarrhea? No
- Have you had any recent infections or illnesses that could be related to your current symptoms? No

Notes:
I do not have any blood test results at the moment.

question: A 27-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for foot pain. The patient states that she has pain in her foot and toes whenever she exerts herself or is at work. The patient is an executive at a medical device company and works 60 hours/week. She is currently training for a marathon. She has a past medical history of anxiety, constipation, and irritable bowel syndrome. Her current medications include clonazepam, sodium docusate, and hyoscyamine. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are within normal limits. Examination of the lower extremity reveals 5/5 strength with 2+ reflexes. Palpation of the interdigital space between the third and fourth toes elicits pain and a clicking sound. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
generalPublicQuestion: I have been feeling pain in my foot and toes, especially when I am moving around or working. I have a busy job as an executive and I am also getting ready for a marathon. I have had anxiety, constipation, and irritable bowel syndrome in the past, and I take medicine for them. My temperature is a little higher than normal, and my blood pressure and pulse are lower than usual. During the check-up, the doctor noticed that pressing between my third and fourth toes made me feel pain and hear a clicking sound. I'm wondering what could be causing this pain in my foot and toes.
surveyQuestions:
I have been feeling pain in my foot and toes, especially when I am moving around or working. I have a busy job as an executive and I am also getting ready for a marathon. I have had anxiety, constipation, and irritable bowel syndrome in the past, and I take medicine for them. My temperature is a little higher than normal, and my blood pressure and pulse are lower than usual. During the check-up, the doctor noticed that pressing between my third and fourth toes made me feel pain and hear a clicking sound. I'm wondering what could be causing this pain in my foot and toes.A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any numbness or tingling in your foot or toes? Yes, I have been experiencing numbness and tingling in my toes.
- Do you notice any swelling, redness, or warmth in the affected area? I have noticed some swelling and warmth in the area.
- Have you recently increased your physical activity or changed your footwear? I have not changed my footwear recently, but I have increased my physical activity.
- Are there any specific movements or activities that worsen the pain in your foot and toes? Walking or standing for long periods worsens the pain.
- Have you had any recent injuries or traumas to your foot or toes? No, I have not had any recent injuries.
- Are you currently experiencing any other symptoms such as weakness or instability in the foot? I have been experiencing some weakness in my foot.
- Have you had any recent changes in weight or diet that may be relevant? There have been no recent changes in weight or diet.
- Are you currently taking any new medications or supplements that could be contributing to your symptoms? No, I am not taking any new medications or supplements.

question: A 24-year-old man and his mother arrive for a psychiatric evaluation. She is concerned about his health and behavior ever since he dropped out of graduate school and moved back home 8 months ago. He is always very anxious and preoccupied with thoughts of school and getting a job. He also seems to behave very oddly at times such as wearing his winter jacket in summer. He says that he hears voices but he can not understand what they are saying. When prompted he describes a plot to have him killed with poison seeping from the walls. Today, his heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, and temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F). On physical exam, he appears gaunt and anxious. His heart has a regular rate and rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. CMP, CBC, and TSH are normal. A urine toxicology test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
generalPublicQuestion: I'm a 24-year-old man and my mom is worried about me. I've been feeling anxious and strange ever since I left school and came back home 8 months ago. I can't stop thinking about school and finding a job. Sometimes I do weird things like wearing my winter jacket in the summer. I hear voices but I don't know what they're saying. When asked, I think there's a plan to poison me through the walls. Today, the doctor checked me and said I look thin and nervous. My heart sounds normal and my lungs are clear. My blood tests and urine test are normal too. What could be wrong with me?
surveyQuestions:
I'm a 24-year-old man and my mom is worried about me. I've been feeling anxious and strange ever since I left school and came back home 8 months ago. I can't stop thinking about school and finding a job. Sometimes I do weird things like wearing my winter jacket in the summer. I hear voices but I don't know what they're saying. When asked, I think there's a plan to poison me through the walls. Today, the doctor checked me and said I look thin and nervous. My heart sounds normal and my lungs are clear. My blood tests and urine test are normal too. What could be wrong with me?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any changes in your sleep patterns, such as difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep? Yes, I have been having trouble falling asleep and staying asleep.
- Do you have trouble concentrating or making decisions? Yes, I have trouble concentrating and making decisions.
- Have you noticed a change in your appetite, either eating more or less than usual? I have noticed a change in my appetite, I have been eating less than usual.
- Are you experiencing any physical symptoms like headaches, stomach aches, or muscle tension? Yes, I have been experiencing headaches and muscle tension.
- Have you had any thoughts of harming yourself or others? No
- Have you ever been diagnosed with a mental health condition before? No

question:
A 33-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a wellness check-up. She states that recently she has been feeling well other than headaches that occur occasionally, which improve with ibuprofen and rest. She has a past medical history of hypertension and headaches and is currently taking hydrochlorothiazide. Her temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 157/108 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals a young woman who appears healthy. A normal S1 and S2 are auscultated on cardiac exam, and her lungs are clear with good air movement bilaterally. From her previous visit, it was determined that she has an elevated aldosterone and low renin level. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 3.7 mEq/L
HCO3-: 29 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
generalPublicQuestion: I have been feeling well lately, but I've been having occasional headaches that get better when I rest and take ibuprofen. I have high blood pressure and a history of headaches. I take hydrochlorothiazide for my blood pressure. The doctor listened to my heart and lungs and said everything sounds normal. Last time, they found that my aldosterone was high and renin was low. My recent lab results show normal sodium, chloride, potassium, and creatinine levels, but high bicarbonate and BUN levels. What could be causing these symptoms?
surveyQuestions:
I have been feeling well lately, but I've been having occasional headaches that get better when I rest and take ibuprofen. I have high blood pressure and a history of headaches. I take hydrochlorothiazide for my blood pressure. The doctor listened to my heart and lungs and said everything sounds normal. Last time, they found that my aldosterone was high and renin was low. My recent lab results show normal sodium, chloride, potassium, and creatinine levels, but high bicarbonate and BUN levels. What could be causing these symptoms?I have not experienced any changes in my vision or visual disturbances during these headaches.
I have been experiencing nausea and sensitivity to light during these headaches.
I have not noticed any specific patterns or triggers for these headaches.
The headaches do not seem to be more frequent at a particular time of day or in specific situations.
There have been no recent changes in my medication regimen or dosage.
I have not experienced any dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting spells along with these headaches.

question: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and repeated falls. Neurologic examination shows past-pointing on a finger-nose test. She has a broad-based gait. Ophthalmologic exam shows rhythmic leftward movement of the globes. A serum antibody assay is positive for anti-Yo antibodies directed at proteins expressed by Purkinje cells. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following tumors?
generalPublicQuestion: I have been feeling dizzy, nauseous, and vomiting for the past week. I have also been falling down a lot. When the doctor checked me, I had trouble touching my finger to my nose and my walking was unsteady. They also noticed that my eyes were moving rhythmically to the left. My blood test showed positive for anti-Yo antibodies that target certain brain cells. What type of tumor is most likely causing these symptoms?
surveyQuestions:
I have been feeling dizzy, nauseous, and vomiting for the past week. I have also been falling down a lot. When the doctor checked me, I had trouble touching my finger to my nose and my walking was unsteady. They also noticed that my eyes were moving rhythmically to the left. My blood test showed positive for anti-Yo antibodies that target certain brain cells. What type of tumor is most likely causing these symptoms?A: Additional Information:
Have you experienced any changes in vision or hearing? No
Have you noticed any weakness or numbness in your limbs? No
Have you had any headaches or changes in your speech? No
Have you experienced any memory problems or confusion? No
Have you had any recent unexplained weight loss? No
Do you have a history of cancer or any autoimmune disorders? No

question: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent otitis media since birth. The patient’s immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows multiple petechiae and several eczematous lesions over the scalp and extremities. The remainder of the examination reveals no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 9,600/mm3 (61% neutrophils and 24% lymphocytes), a platelet count of 29,000/mm3, and an increased serum IgE concentration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
generalPublicQuestion: I am an 11-month-old boy who has been having ear infections often since I was born. I have received all my vaccinations on time. I am a bit smaller than other kids my age. During my recent visit to the doctor, they noticed small red or purple spots on my skin and some itchy patches on my head and arms. Everything else during my check-up was okay. Some of the numbers in my blood tests were not normal. I wonder what could be causing all of this?
surveyQuestions:
I am an 11-month-old boy who has been having ear infections often since I was born. I have received all my vaccinations on time. I am a bit smaller than other kids my age. During my recent visit to the doctor, they noticed small red or purple spots on my skin and some itchy patches on my head and arms. Everything else during my check-up was okay. Some of the numbers in my blood tests were not normal. I wonder what could be causing all of this?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any fever or unusual tiredness recently? Yes, I have been feeling more tired than usual.
- Are the red or purple spots flat or raised? Do they blanch when pressed? The spots are raised and do not blanch when pressed.
- Do the itchy patches on your head and arms have any specific appearance or texture? The itchy patches are red and scaly.
- Have you had any recent changes in your diet or exposure to new environments? No, there have been no recent changes in my diet or exposure to new environments.
- Are there any other symptoms such as cough, runny nose, or diarrhea that you have been experiencing? No, I have not experienced any cough, runny nose, or diarrhea.

question: A 4-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician for severe developmental delay. On exam he is noted to have macroorchidism, hypertelorism, large protruding ears, a large jaw, and a long thin face. Suspicious of what the diagnosis may be, the pediatrician orders a PCR and DNA sequencing. The results reveal an expansion of 250 repeats of CGG. What is the diagnosis of the boy?
generalPublicQuestion: I have a 4-year-old boy who is having trouble with his development. He has some physical features like big ears, a big jaw, and a long, thin face. The doctor also noticed that his testicles are larger than usual. The doctor did some tests and found out that he has a certain number of repeats of CGG in his DNA. Can you help me figure out what might be going on with him?
surveyQuestions:
I have a 4-year-old boy who is having trouble with his development. He has some physical features like big ears, a big jaw, and a long, thin face. The doctor also noticed that his testicles are larger than usual. The doctor did some tests and found out that he has a certain number of repeats of CGG in his DNA. Can you help me figure out what might be going on with him?A: Additional Information:
- My son has experienced delays in reaching developmental milestones such as walking and talking.
- He is showing signs of intellectual disability and learning difficulties.
- I have noticed behavioral issues and challenges in his daily activities.
- There is no known family history of genetic disorders or conditions.
- Apart from the mentioned features, there are no other physical or medical concerns at this time.

question: A 25-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and discomfort for the past 3 days. She was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) a couple of years ago, managed until recently with imipramine, psyllium, and loperamide. 5 days ago, because she had developed alternating diarrhea and constipation, bloating, and abdominal pain on her medication, she was started on alosetron. Her current temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), the heart rate is 115/min, the blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and the respiratory rate is 22/min. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with guarding but no rebound. Bowel sounds are hypoactive on auscultation. A fecal occult blood test is positive and laboratory tests show her white cell count to be 15,800/µL. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals a metabolic acidosis Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
generalPublicQuestion: I have been feeling stomach pain and discomfort for the past 3 days. A few years ago, I was told I have irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). To manage it, I take imipramine, psyllium, and loperamide. Lately, I've been having alternating diarrhea and constipation, bloating, and more stomach pain even with my medication. I started taking alosetron 5 days ago. My temperature is higher than normal, my heart rate is faster, and my stomach hurts when touched. A test showed blood in my stool, and my white cell count is higher than usual. The test also showed that I have a metabolic acidosis. I wonder what could be causing all these symptoms in me?
surveyQuestions:
I have been feeling stomach pain and discomfort for the past 3 days. A few years ago, I was told I have irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). To manage it, I take imipramine, psyllium, and loperamide. Lately, I've been having alternating diarrhea and constipation, bloating, and more stomach pain even with my medication. I started taking alosetron 5 days ago. My temperature is higher than normal, my heart rate is faster, and my stomach hurts when touched. A test showed blood in my stool, and my white cell count is higher than usual. The test also showed that I have a metabolic acidosis. I wonder what could be causing all these symptoms in me?A: Additional Information:
- Have you experienced any unintentional weight loss recently? Yes, I have experienced some unintentional weight loss.
- Are you experiencing any nausea or vomiting along with the stomach pain? Yes, I am experiencing nausea and vomiting along with the stomach pain.
- Have you noticed any changes in the color or consistency of your stool? Yes, there have been changes in the color and consistency of my stool.
- Do you have a history of any other gastrointestinal conditions besides IBS? No, I do not have a history of any other gastrointestinal conditions besides IBS.
- Have you traveled recently or been in contact with anyone who is sick? No, I have not traveled recently or been in contact with anyone who is sick.

question: A 4-month-old is noted to have a grade 3/6, harsh, systolic ejection murmur heard at the left upper sternal border. The mother reports that the child's lips occasionally turn blue during feeding. A cardiologist recommends surgery. Later, the physician remarks that the infant's congenital abnormality was related to a failure of neural crest cell migration. Prior to surgery, which of the following was a likely finding?
generalPublicQuestion: Before the surgery, the doctor might have noticed that the baby with the heart problem was having trouble breathing, getting tired easily, or not growing as well as expected. The baby might have had a bluish tint to their skin or lips, which can happen when the heart is not pumping enough oxygen-rich blood to the body. The doctor may have also heard abnormal sounds when listening to the baby's heart with a stethoscope. These signs could have indicated that the baby had a heart problem that needed to be fixed with surgery.
surveyQuestions:
Before the surgery, the doctor might have noticed that the baby with the heart problem was having trouble breathing, getting tired easily, or not growing as well as expected. The baby might have had a bluish tint to their skin or lips, which can happen when the heart is not pumping enough oxygen-rich blood to the body. The doctor may have also heard abnormal sounds when listening to the baby's heart with a stethoscope. These signs could have indicated that the baby had a heart problem that needed to be fixed with surgery.A: Additional Information:
- Did the baby have any other symptoms such as sweating excessively during feeds, poor feeding, or difficulty gaining weight? Yes, I experienced sweating excessively during feeds and had difficulty gaining weight.
- Were there any episodes of sudden crying, irritability, or lethargy in the baby? Yes, I experienced episodes of sudden crying and irritability.
- Did the baby have any previous heart conditions or surgeries? No, I did not have any previous heart conditions or surgeries.
- Were there any specific diagnostic tests done to confirm the heart problem, such as an echocardiogram or ECG? Yes, an echocardiogram was done to confirm the heart problem.
- Were there any specific concerns or complications mentioned by the doctor regarding the heart surgery? The doctor mentioned concerns about potential complications during the heart surgery.
